<title level="1" pfs="Standard">[Raja Rakshasa](/Monsters.aspx?ID=345)</title>

<row gap="medium">

<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">

When not disguised as a humanoid, the raja rakshasa has the head of an animal. The hands of a raja rakshasa are more subtly unsettling, for the fingers of these fiends bend outward, away from the palms.

 More than any other types of rakshasa, rajas scoff at religion. They understand the power of the divine, yet they view themselves as the only things worthy of worship from mortal creatures; not even their own immortals are deemed deserving of such glorification. Raja rakshasas often form close-knit families that work together to bring down mortal cities or to rule them from the shadows within. Such families of rakshasas often incorporate other breeds of the fiend, often using dandasukas as favored servants or stealthy spies. Even though a raja family works together to achieve a shared goal, infighting and treachery among their own is a constant threat.

</column>

<title level="2" right="Creature 10">[Raja Rakshasa](/Monsters.aspx?ID=345)</title>

<traits>
<trait label="LE" url="/Rules.aspx?ID=95" />
<trait label="Medium" />
<trait label="Fiend" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=70" />
<trait label="Rakshasa" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=233" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Bestiary](/Sources.aspx?ID=2) pg. 275</row>

**Perception** +19; darkvision

**Languages**
[Common](/Languages.aspx?ID=1), [Infernal](/Languages.aspx?ID=19), [Undercommon](/Languages.aspx?ID=11)

**Skills**
[Deception](/Skills.aspx?ID=5) +23, [Diplomacy](/Skills.aspx?ID=6) +21, [Intimidation](/Skills.aspx?ID=7) +21, [Performance](/Skills.aspx?ID=12) +19, [Occultism](/Skills.aspx?ID=11) +18, [Stealth](/Skills.aspx?ID=15) +20

<row gap="medium">
**Str** +4

**Dex** +6

**Con** +4

**Int** +2

**Wis** +1

**Cha** +5
</row>

**Items**
_+1 [striking](/Equipment.aspx?ID=280) [kukri](/Weapons.aspx?ID=56)_

</column>

---

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="medium">
**AC** 30 

**Fort** +19 

**Ref** +21 

**Will** +18 

+2 status to all saves vs. magic, +3 status to all saves vs. divine magic
</row>

**HP** 155

**Resistances**
physical 10 (except piercing)

**Weaknesses**
good 10

**Scoff at the Divine** <actions string="Reaction" /> **Trigger** A creature within 30 feet casts a divine spell or uses a divine ability. **Requirements** The raja rakshasa has an unexpended spell slot that can be used to cast [_dispel magic_](/Spells.aspx?ID=78). **Effect** The raja rakshasa expends a spell slot that could be used to cast dispel magic and attempts to counteract the triggering spell or ability. The raja rakshasa can’t Scoff at the Divine for 1d4 rounds.

</column>

---

<column gap="tiny">

**Speed** 35 feet

**Melee**
<actions string="Single Action" />
_kukri_ +23 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170), [Finesse](/Traits.aspx?ID=179), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103), [Trip](/Traits.aspx?ID=196)),
**Damage** 2d6+10 slashing

**Melee**
<actions string="Single Action" />
fangs +20 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103)),
**Damage** 2d12+10 piercing

**Melee**
<actions string="Single Action" />
claw +22 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170), [Finesse](/Traits.aspx?ID=179), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103)),
**Damage** 2d8+10 slashing

**Occult Spontaneous Spells** DC 31
- **Cantrips (5th)**
[Detect Magic](/Spells.aspx?ID=66), [Ghost Sound](/Spells.aspx?ID=132), [Mage Hand](/Spells.aspx?ID=177), [Read Aura](/Spells.aspx?ID=246), [Sigil](/Spells.aspx?ID=286)
- **1st**
[Charm](/Spells.aspx?ID=34), [Illusory Object](/Spells.aspx?ID=160), [Item Facade](/Spells.aspx?ID=166) (4 slots)
- **2nd**
[Blur](/Spells.aspx?ID=28), [Hideous Laughter](/Spells.aspx?ID=150), [Invisibility](/Spells.aspx?ID=164) (4 slots)
- **3rd**
[Clairaudience](/Spells.aspx?ID=39), [Dispel Magic](/Spells.aspx?ID=78), [Nondetection](/Spells.aspx?ID=209), [Vampiric Touch](/Spells.aspx?ID=354) (4 slots)
- **4th**
[Clairvoyance](/Spells.aspx?ID=40), [Dispel Magic](/Spells.aspx?ID=78), [Fly](/Spells.aspx?ID=125), [Suggestion](/Spells.aspx?ID=315) (4 slots)
- **5th**
[Dispel Magic](/Spells.aspx?ID=78), [Hallucination](/Spells.aspx?ID=144), [Shadow Blast](/Spells.aspx?ID=273) (3 slots)

**Occult Innate Spells** DC 31
- **3rd**
[Mind Reading](/Spells.aspx?ID=194) (at will)

**[Change Shape](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=8)** <actions string="Single Action" /> ([Concentrate](/Traits.aspx?ID=32), [Occult](/Traits.aspx?ID=120), [Polymorph](/Traits.aspx?ID=127), [Transmutation](/Traits.aspx?ID=157)) The raja rakshasa takes on the appearance of any Medium humanoid. This doesn’t change the raja rakshasa’s Speed or its attack and damage modifiers with its Strikes but might change the damage type its Strikes deal (typically to bludgeoning). It typically loses its fangs Strike unless the humanoid form has fangs or a similar unarmed attack.

**Disturbing Vision** <actions string="Single Action" /> ([Concentrate](/Traits.aspx?ID=32), [Enchantment](/Traits.aspx?ID=61), [Mental](/Traits.aspx?ID=106), [Occult](/Traits.aspx?ID=120)) The raja rakshasa’s eyes flash green as it projects a telepathic wave in a 30-foot emanation. All creatures in the area are assailed by a vision of evil decadence from one of the rakshasa’s past lives. Each non-evil creature in the area must succeed at a DC 29 Will save or become [sickened 1](/Conditions.aspx?ID=34) (and [stunned 1](/Conditions.aspx?ID=36) on a critical failure). The visions last 1d4 rounds, and while they do, the raja rakshasa and all evil creatures in the area gain a +1 status bonus to all checks. The raja rakshasa can use this ability again only once the previous visions end.

</column>

<aside>
<title level="2" noclass="true" icon="/images/Icons/Sidebar_2_AdditionalLore.png">Raja Heads</title>

Raja's heads often resemble those of cats or snakes, but they can also be similar to apes, jackals, vultures, elephants, mantises, lizards, rhinos, boars, and more are possible. In most cases, the type of head a raja rakshasa possesses symbolizes its personality—a tiger-headed one is stealthy and ravenous, while a boar-headed one might be gluttonous and crude.
</aside>
